content:
Hey everyone, this is my first message here.
I recently finished the Natural Number Game, and I wish to learn more about how the real numbers are constructed using Lean4, similar to how I have learnt about the natural numbers so far. Is there any Lean4 book/online material that could guide me toward this, or is my best bet to pick up a Real Analysis textbook and solve problems in that using lean?
Do you want to learn the math or to learn how to write proofs in Lean?

Unfortunately mathlib is not a good source to learn the math: everything is written in a great generality, and this makes it very difficult to understand if you don't know already what you're talking about. (Being a pedagogical tool it's not at all one of the goal of mathlib)

Riccardo Brasca said:

Do you want to learn the math or to learn how to write proofs in Lean?

Both, actually. I was expecting to learn them both simultaneously, similar to the Natural Number Game. But judging by your next message, seems like it isn't ideal to learn it from mathlib itself. The thing is, I prefer this style of writing proofs quite a bit more than the traditional style, and so I'm looking for any material that develops real numbers in the same way natural numbers were developed through NNG.
There is a Real Number Game developed by @Kevin Buzzard and others, though this is in Lean 3.

Oh that project is pretty much abandoned. I would look at the tutorial project if you want to learn how to do real analysis in lean. Did this get ported? I see https://github.com/PatrickMassot/GlimpseOfLean/blob/master/GlimpseOfLean/Exercises/Topics/SequenceLimits.lean in lean 4.
There is also https://github.com/leanprover-community/tutorials4/, and of course almost all those exercises are in MIL.
Oh -- so we are directing newcomers not to the tutorials project but to MIL now?
It depends on how much time they have and their learning style. This is hopefully explained at https://leanprover-community.github.io/learn.html
Vivek Rajesh Joshi has marked this topic as resolved.
